title: Robot
dialogue_triumphs: The Brigadier on neutral monitoring of superpower missile bases: 'Naturally enough, the only country that could be trusted with such a role was Great Britain.' 'Naturally,' says the Doctor. 'I mean, the rest were all foreigners.'
goofs: K1 with doll Sarah and Action Man tank. His legs keep vanishing as well.
The SRS goes to great lengths to get the disintegrator gun, and then all they use it for is to blow open a safe door.
Miss Winters' feminist views don't accord with SRS views on women.
Kettlewell changes from a good boffin to the villain of the piece in a most unconvincing way.
Jellicoe can't decide if he's a squeamish villain or a Nazi maniac.
The robot's motives change from scene to scene and show contradictory programming.
The Doctor chops a brick in half, but it's clearly a block of balsa wood.

untold_adventures: The Doctor's receipt of the 'freedom of the city of Skaro' from the Thals
The Doctor's experiences with the Alpha Centauri table tennis club
additional_notes: The Doctor's pockets contain jelly babies, a scroll said to be the 'freedom of the city of Skaro', a pilot's licence on the Mars-Venus rocket run, a galactic passport, and honorary membership of the Alpha Centauri table tennis club.
bottom_line: A steady, rather than spectacular, start for the new Doctor. A fun runaround, with lots of good bits, rather spoiled by silly scenes with the robot.
